intro: Papaver pseudoradicatum, commonly known as the false root poppy, is a rare and striking plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family, which includes other poppies known for their showy flowers and medicinal properties. The plant features delicate, pale pink to white flowers with a distinctive, saucer-shaped corolla and a central stigma that resembles a crown. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stem is slender and often hairy. Papaver pseudoradicatum is typically found in rocky, arid environments and is adapted to thrive in harsh, high-altitude conditions.
